text: [Music]
What's going on everybody? Mortem here.
This time bringing you my review after
100% for Clare Obscure Expedition 33. A
sort of western JRPG drenched in
surrealism, interesting combat
mechanics, and a really great story
about family and grief. But before we
get into all that, to get my usual stuff
out of the way, I review games after
100% all the time to set me apart from
other reviewers on the platform. And
while that does include the achievements
and also includes a lot more than that,
there's a video linked below that will
cover everything I go over and my Steam
profile is public and linked below as
well. In the case of this game, as I am
bringing you this review about one day
before its official release, it's
probably pretty obvious then that I
received a review key for this. In fact,
I received it all the way back at the
beginning of April. So, I had this game
for quite some time and thus I was able
to pretty comfortably get this done.
What's more, uh before that even I had
also participated in an early preview
where they basically just gave you
access to a build to check out. And from
that preview, my main takeaway was
simply that I think whether or not you
enjoy this game, you know, a lot or a
little basically comes down to how much
you wind up enjoying the combat that
that would be pretty make or break for
people. And while I think this game does
have more going on than that, that is
definitely something that was reaffirmed
throughout my time with the game, and
we'll get into that obviously. But
before we do, uh, just a note on
spoilers. We are a day ahead of the
game's official release here. And this
game has a pretty big emphasis on its
story. There's some huge twists and
reveals, and obviously I don't really
want to go into any of that or spoil
that for anybody. So, while I'm not
really going to talk about these things,
uh there might be some contextual stuff
in the footage that I'm going to try to
avoid showing, but due to the sort of
nature of those uh reveals and changes
that happen throughout the game, it's
actually kind of hard not to show them
because of how it affects things just
like menus as an example. So, because of
that, you may just want to listen
instead of watch this. From there, let's
talk a little bit about the game itself.
So, as I mentioned, great story about
family and grief. As this takes place in
a world where the paintress, a large
mysterious figure far away near a
monolith, will once a year rise up,
paint a descending number onto a
monolith, and then everyone that age or
above kind of just disintegrates and
fades away. And so, the people of this
area have been sending out expeditions
in order to, you know, do something
about this. And then, unsurprisingly, we
are playing as expedition 33. And while
this game has some fun combat, I wanted
to say that right at the beginning here
because the game touches a lot on themes
of again loss and grief and how they can
overwhelm a person, how people cope with
those things, etc. And it winds up going
some pretty dark places, but if you're
willing to follow through with it, it
really is a fantastic story. And I think
that might get a little undersold thanks
to things just like the interesting
combat mechanics and the surrealism in
the art. Now, I say combat's probably
going to be make or break for this.
mostly because it comes down a lot to
QTE. And with my experience with this
game, uh, difficulty that says it
reduces the need to rely on those
things, I found to not have that crazy
of an effect on them. So, when enemies
attack you, you'll have to try to dodge
or parry to mitigate damage. In fact,
you can just no hit bosses and
everything if you manage to do this
well. Now, there's not much you can do
about that. That just is the combat
mechanics. Now, on the flip side, when
you attack enemies, there are sometimes
little QTE to perform extra effects or
damage. And in some extreme cases, even
avoid damage to yourself or failing the
attack at all. In the options, you can
set those to auto sort of work, so you
don't have to worry about those. But the
incoming stuff isn't a negotiable aspect
of this game. And as I mentioned, while
the difficulty options say it's going to
reduce the reliance on this after
playing around with all three
difficulties, which you can freely
change, I found that to not really be
true in most cases, especially for the
optional stuff. Maybe it's true for the
critical path, which is frankly a bit
easier than some of the optional in-game
things. Because with that stuff, um,
frankly, those enemies and bosses will
one-shot you if you miss those things on
any difficulty you're playing on. So
much so that I actually wouldn't be
surprised if this winds up getting a
balance pass because I literally
couldn't tell you the difference between
most of those. But from there, let's
talk the technical state. I had this
game for a while. How was it running?
So, two things I wanted to note here are
primarily that uh unfortunately I did
have a lot of crashes over roughly 60
hours with this game. It crashed at
least a dozen times. I kind of just
stopped counting after a little while. I
always do a little bit of research into
the why when that kind of thing happens
and I could not track down a specific
cause, at least on my own. Uh sometimes
problems with drivers will cause that
sort of thing, especially with review
copies. And with this being ahead of the
official release, I don't know how it's
going to run for everybody else, but
again, left a bit to be desired there.
Now, what's more in this section of the
video, I actually wanted to mention that
the game does feature quite a few
options to again customize little stuff
like, you know, do you want to be
affected by QTS on your abilities, stuff
like that. and it may be worth engaging
with that stuff to kind of figure out if
this is uh up your alley, so to speak,
or if that would be something you want.
But moving on from there, let's talk
about difficulty. So, my main thing
about difficulty that I already
mentioned is that I felt little
difference between them because of how
the active elements of combat work, but
we do have three options essentially,
easy, normal, hard, and what they are
supposed to do is affect enemy damage
and then how easy those dodge and
parries are to pull off. But to
reiterate, I felt very little difference
between any of these, not least of which
because it is pretty easy overall to
deal with the uh sort of critical path
through the story either by just
overleveling or grinding as with many
JRPGs, which is going to eliminate most
of the difficulty there, especially once
the game opens up and you can kind of do
everything before the sort of end scene.
But when it comes to the optional stuff
like the super bosses, endgame optional
encounters, stuff like that, a lot of
those guys have abilities that are
basically one shots if you miss the
dodge or the parry or anything like
that. And as a result of that being on
every single difficulty, it really just
reinforced my feeling that if you don't
enjoy this type of combat, you're
probably just not going to enjoy this
game. But if you like it, it's a pretty
great time. That brings me to the story
setup and my thoughts on that. So again,
going to try to avoid spoilers here. Not
going in depth on a lot of this simply
because of the fact that we're ahead of
the release date, and it's also a really
good story that I want people to
experience. But again, we are playing as
expedition 33, embarking on a quest to
do something about the painter painting
numbers on a monolith, resulting in the
death of everybody above that age. This
has been going on for roughly 67 years
at the time of the beginning of the
game. And the story is, frankly, all
about that journey. But not only that
journey, but also asking questions like
why is this happening? What is this all
about? Who all of these people are? And
then it also deals with heavy themes
surrounding things like grief and loss
and just, you know, family dealing with
those things. As right at the start of
the game, you see that every year when
this event happens and it takes the
people of those new numbers, they
experience that all over again,
especially in town. And it's obviously
dominated their society as that age gets
lower and lower. and getting the
opportunity to see both of the sort of
zoomed out version of all that stuff,
but then how it relates to individual
characters that are affected by all
this, which you can witness at camp
cutscenes with the playable characters
will be involved in. Makes for some
really touching moments in my opinion.
Now, I'll go over the individual
characters uh in the combat section. I
don't want to get into it too much here
because again, I don't want to spoil
their narrative arcs. So, I'll simply
say that the only one I wound up
disliking was Manokco, the sort of
comedic relief gestal, which are these
kind of like humanoid paint brushes that
love to fight everything. He honestly
felt a little forced, but the rest of it
was a really good time. From there,
though, let's talk progression system.
So, this is something this game has
quite a few of everything from
individual character progression,
exploration progression via our sort of
secondary companion named Esquy, who
winds up being this game's equivalent of
an airship towards the end, but can also
swim and simply get you through land
barriers at the same time. But let's
focus on individual characters. So,
every character has the level ups
associated with typical RPGs like this.
As usual, as they level up, their base
stats increase, making them stronger
simply by being a higher level. In
addition to that though, we also gain
skills and attributes every level. At
the game's various checkpoints is where
we'll be able to increase these, but we
get one skill point per level, and as
those accumulate, we can buy new skills
to use in combat once we have action
points. And then we also get three
attributes. You can put these in
anything you want really. But it's
important to note that uh the weapons,
which are your main bit of equipment
that you'll assign to each character,
also scale off of different uh
attributes. So, what I found to be the
most effective was to give everybody at
least a little vitality to help them
survive, and then focus kind of all in
on might and whatever their weapons are
scaling off of. After that, you will
ultimately have enough attribute points
to max out about three of these, give or
take. So, you got plenty of room to mess
around with. And for the most part, they
simply increase the secondary stats that
you can see to the right there. Now,
weapons are interesting because they
often have a damage type associated with
them, typically physical or then some
other element. Some skills work off of
whatever element your weapon is, and
then obviously your base attacks take
that into account, which is especially
important because enemies have
resistances and weaknesses, meaning that
if you want to optimize, you'll probably
want to be switching out weapons every
so often, which requires keeping them
leveled up. Your weapons also can be
upgraded. They have their base level you
find them at, and if you find
duplicates, it always overwrites it to
the highest level you found. But
upgrading these with various upgrade
materials you can find around first at
the curator who will show up in your
camp. And then later on, you can
actually just do it at the checkpoints.
And this will of course just increase
how effective that weapon is, requiring
more and more resources as you go up to
a maximum of 33 if you'd believe it. But
because of the fact that you might want
to switch these out on occasion, you may
want to upgrade various weapons for
various situations, as honestly you will
probably wind up with more upgrade
materials than you need if you're
properly exploring. But then there's the
other major progression system, which is
pictos and luminina. So pictos are
effectively like equipable accessories.
They all have stats and an effect
associated with them. When you have
pictos equipped, once you partake in
four battles with them equipped, you
then learn the special effect associated
with that picto, which is known as a
luminina. Lumina can then be equipped
for all of your characters at that
point. So, you only need to learn them
once per character, and then all of your
characters can learn them at that point.
Every time your character levels up,
they also gain one Lumina point. And
then there is an item called color of
luminina that you can use to upgrade the
overall capacity for any individual
character. Personally, I found about 250
to 300 points per character at a max
level to be where I could make a really
strong setup for them. But basically, we
spend these Lumina points then to equip
all of the effects from these pictos.
And that in combination with the other
stuff makes that character's sort of
build for you. Now, the somewhat catch
to this is you have to remember that the
actual pictos you equip do have stats
associated with them. So sometimes
you'll want to equip certain pictos
because of those stats as well and then
have other stuff filled out via the
aluminina list, but obviously the
minutiae of that is going to be up to
you. Just something to note for sure.
Though obviously the most valuable stuff
comes in the late game, which is things
that let you break the initial damage
limit of
9,999 or the ability to just grant your
character two turns in a row, which is
going to help you dominate just via
action economy, which by the way is
essentially required for the optional
late game stuff. Now, other than all
that, there's just one more minor system
I want to mention, and that is the
potions. So, we get various potions and
elixir to carry with us to use in combat
between rests at checkpoints, which are
going to allow us to either full heal
our party or uh heal, give action
points, or revive characters in combat.
We start out with one each of these, but
you can find charges of them as you
explore, which will increase the amount
of times you can do this in between
actual rests. That brings us to game
play and world. Now, for the most part,
I would say if you've ever played a
JRPG, you'll probably feel right at home
in terms of how this game actually plays
from that perspective. That is to say,
we have an overworld system where we'll
run around, have encounters, even find
items and secrets as usual. But that
overworld map allows you to enter
various locations. Worth a mention that
areas far beyond your level will be
marked as danger on the world map. And
for the most part, I actually found that
little message to be super accurate. It
was usually worthwhile to level up until
that little disclaimer fell off. And
then at that point, I was pretty much
good to go every single time. Now, as
you're moving through the story, it will
mark the locations that you need to head
on your map as the world map is a pretty
decent size and it's easy to get a
little turned around, but luckily that
little quality of life feature will keep
you on track and you can just focus on
the critical path if you want. But there
is a whole host of optional stuff. Now,
as you explore that world map, you can
find shortcuts for traversal, especially
when you are initially landlocked before
you get access to Esquy. And through
these shortcuts, you can just make paths
over like mountains and stuff, which
makes getting around a little bit
easier. And then once you actually get
access to Esquy, it can destroy blocks
and stuff in your way, allowing you to
get into places you couldn't before you
can then swim and fly later. So, there's
all that, but let's talk about the
individual levels when we're on foot
exploring a given area. So this is where
the game in addition to things like the
attributes I would say definitely takes
some notes from souls like in terms of
level design. Not so much uh combat
really but in terms of their level
design you can definitely kind of see
the influence there. That is to say we
see things like checkpoints where we can
rest to uh respawn enemies if you're
interested in grinding up some levels or
you just want to knock out your pictos
or something. And this is also where
you'll level up, refuel and whatnot
before going on about the level. And
then as you do that, you can also unlock
shortcuts to more quickly traverse
through a given area that stay active in
between rests and everything. So
functionally speaking, you can
definitely see where they got some of
those ideas from. But as you can no
doubt see as we move through a given
area, a pretty big aspect to exploration
is just the sort of surrealism happening
in the background. seeing all of these
creatures that have been painted into
existence known as Nevrons whose sole
purpose seems to be wiping people out
that they come across in order to
maintain some sort of order. Unbeknownst
to you when you initially encounter
them, forming a sort of background
mystery that you can also somewhat
investigate because occasionally some of
these guys will be friendly and offer
short little side quests where you get
some more information, which is often
how you can uncover secrets and just
optional content in general. And then
simply as part of the main story, you'll
also learn about all sorts of things
like the gesturals, the somewhat
peaceful sort of humanoid paintbrush
guys that I mentioned who love to fight
everything that moves. Now, these guys
aren't exactly an inherent danger, but
through their love to fight, they may
wind up injuring people unintentionally,
and we kind of see that reflected
through certain bits of the game. So,
these guys aren't exactly safe to be
around, but they're not actively trying
to cause you a problem either, which is
also something you can see in the form
of their merchants, who typically all
have a sort of secret inventory that you
have to fight the merchant in a solo
fight to unlock. And you can even find
them doing stuff like setting up bouts
of various games that they like to play
on locations throughout the world map,
typically beach locations. And this is
where you can even see some like
platforming type sections. And to be
fair, the game while offering up a lot
of this platforming here or there, I
also don't think has the precision of
movement required to fully implement
systems like that. So, I didn't exactly
love these little platforming sections,
but they are in there. And all of that
kind of stuff is what you can expect to
see from Expedition 33. And I think they
do a fantastic job of really leaning
into that sort of whimsical surrealism
that is the art style that is obviously
inspired by some French themes which are
especially prevalent in places where
there's a little more civilization. But
before we wrap up this section, I did
want to mention the game's camp system.
When you're out on the overworld, you
can sort of retire to camp, which is
where you'll have a chance to talk to
your companions, which actually leads
into a small other progression system,
which is your relationship level with
those companions, which at a certain
point in the game can be raised, which
gives you access to their sort of limit
breaks called a gradient attack. And
increasing that relationship is how you
unlock the better versions of those
things. And you're going to handle all
of that stuff in camp. And this can even
lead to a few other side quests for your
companions. and it's where you'll get a
lot of their backstory, find out what
they're all about, etc. And I think
that's a pretty well done thing. And
this is also where you'll have the
option if you want to to reflect on your
journey by writing in your own
expedition journal. But for the most
part, I would say the camp is primarily
a place to host various story beats that
they want to hit. From there, let's talk
combat. the part that I think is going
to be make or break for a lot of people
because it is primarily a turnbased
system but has certain active elements
such as quicktime events unsurprisingly,
but also things like uh just timing
dodges and parries out of the way of
enemies to avoid damage entirely,
potentially leading to counterattacks
and the like, but also the ability to
free aim and target enemy weak points
potentially for big damage or just
disrupting certain effects. As an
example of that specific system, there's
actually an optional boss that will uh
shine some lights in a specific pattern.
If you don't disrupt those with free aim
ranged attacks in that order, it will
unleash a devastating hit that is very
hard to counterattack. Now, the
turn-based elements of this are really
straightforward. You know, when it's
your character's turn, based on their
speed stat, which determines how often
they can move, they can perform the
actions available to them, which are
pretty much basic attack, use a skill,
or free aim, or use an item. Skills are
typically better than base attacks, but
not always because they will often have
extra effects associated with them. And
they almost always play into a given
character's sort of play style, and
we'll get into those in a moment. But
each playable character has a sort of
different mechanic that sets them apart
from the others. Now, in order to use
skills, though, we first need action
points. There's a few ways to uh get
more of that, often dictated by the
various bits of Lumina that you have
equipped, but basically every turn and
every time you attack, you will at the
very least gain action points that way.
And then you can also do it when you
dodge or parry based on what you've got
in terms of Lumina. But Lumina, even on
this basic stuff, has really big
effects. For instance, there is Lumina
that will give you extra attacks, extra
action points. In fact, if you defeat an
optional boss relatively early into the
optional in-game stuff, you'll get one
that just straight up gives you a second
turn, which is massive for the late
game. Now, other aspects to this though
are shields and breaks. So, everyone has
access to a shield mechanic. Basically,
these are armor points you can throw on
characters or enemies will throw on
themselves. And each shield fully
deflects one attack. It won't do
anything. And you'll have to chew
through them. That's actually something
that like free aim shots are good for
because free aim shots cost action
points to perform which means you can
actually uh use free aim ranged attacks
to target wheat points or just break
through shields as an example up to the
point at which you just don't have any
more action points at which point you
could say basic attack as an example
which fully buffed up in the late game
is actually a surprisingly effective
strategy and in some cases will even
outdamage your uh skills and abilities
though not always. Now, as we're doing
all of that though, on plenty of
enemies, this will build up a sort of
stun meter. When that stun meter is
full, it doesn't automatically stun the
target, but rather you need to use an
ability or attack that has a break
effect, which will then fully break them
and then stun them or perform some other
effect in certain fights. For instance,
there are these weird mimes you can
encounter, and oftent times they will
just have massively reduced incoming
damage until you break them. But only
some attacks and abilities actually do
this. Now, there is a Luminina that
makes your basic attacks break enemies,
which I found super helpful, by the way,
because a lot of the skills I liked to
use did not have that break effect. But
then, let's get into the dodging and
parrying. So, when enemies attack you,
it is actually very possible to take
zero damage from an encounter. We're
going to do this by dodging and
parrying. Enemies will often attack in
uh combos or just various things like
that. And a lot of times what you're
going to have to figure out is whether
you want to dodge or parry or what you
need to do in that situation. Dodging is
easier, but it does just that. It just
dodges out of the way and prevents you
from taking damage. Parries are more
difficult and require more precise
timing. But if you can parry every
attack in an enemy's combo or just
general attack sequence, skill, or
whatever else, you can then perform a
counterattack on them, which will
typically do a massive hit, increase
their stun gauge, and obviously negate
damage from you at the same time. Some
enemies are more susceptible to this
than others. But if you can master
counterattacking on top of having a
really good build, you can trivialize
most fights, even some of the optional
in-game super bosses. In fact, I would
say it's basically required for the two
bosses that I would consider super
bosses that I ran into, as one of them
heals themselves non-stop if you don't
manage to pull this off, and the other
one basically one-shots you if you fail.
Now, from there, I want to talk about
the individual characters we can use in
combat and what their unique elements
are. So, there are ultimately six
playable characters. We have Gustav. He
has a sort of charge mechanic. So he has
a mechanical arm and as he hits enemies
in combat with his abilities and stuff,
it builds up charge. Depending on the
level of charge, you can then use his
ability overcharge to unleash that which
will deal massive damage and it can even
break enemies as well. Next up, we've
got Lun, a sort of spellcaster. She has
a lot of magical abilities and can also
be your healer if you want, depending on
how you want to mess around with her
skills. But her mechanic is all about
building up stains. So each of her
abilities both generates and consumes
stains. Certain abilities of hers are
then empowered by the types of stains
consumed, potentially leading to extra
effects and the like, which means
ideally there's like a certain order
you'll want to cast stuff in to get the
most out of any individual spell, which
is where she really shines. Following
that though, we then have Mayel. Mel is
all about stances. So each of her
various abilities will alternate her
stance from either just stanceless or
defensive, offensive or virtuoso. So
defensive obviously reduces incoming
damage, offensive increases it and then
virtuos actually increases it massively
by like 200%. And typically the stuff
that puts her in that stance requires
some more specific effects. The easiest
one I found was one that puts that
stance on you when you attack a burning
enemy, which is a relatively easy status
effect to put on an enemy. And that way,
I could reliably trigger it before using
her big abilities like sword ballet. I
will say that she is one of the
characters that benefits massively from
a second turn, which you can get in the
later game really easily, and this is
because of the way that stance system
works. So you can use the first turn to
set up the stance and then the second
turn to actually execute the ability
with the stance you just set up because
she's an incredible damage dealer if you
can manage to set that up properly. Next
is Sel. So she will put uh foretell on
enemies with a lot of her attacks. This
allows her to just basically apply
stacks of an ability which then also
generates charges. And then her consume
abilities will typically provide the
opposite mark. So, sun versus moon and
also consume the foretell stacks. But
when she has both sun and moon marks
from using these abilities, it then puts
her into twilight state based on the
number of those marks that she has. And
twilight state massively increases her
damage, but also allows her to stack
more foretell on enemies to set up for a
potentially massive attack in a way that
is not all that dissimilar from somebody
like say Mel. And then last but not
least, we have Manoko. Monokco is
actually, I would say, the most unique
because he uses that trope of stealing
enemies abilities from them. So, as we
fight Nevron's, Monokco, if he's in your
party, will then steal their feet, which
apparently gives him access to the
skills they use, and that's how he
gathers his abilities. So, his whole
progression system actually works a
little differently because he does not
get a skill tree, he gets these. On top
of that, though, he also has a beast
wheel. Basically, everything he does
spins a wheel so many turns and then
whatever it lands on will empower
certain types of his abilities as they
are all sort of divided up into various
categories. So, all of that's pretty
neat. But, as I mentioned a little bit
earlier, each of these characters also
has a form of limit break called a
gradient attack. They'll get the base
one once you get access to them
generally, but then as your relationship
with each of them increases, you get
access to level two and three as you
attack enemies typically with skills.
But with Luminina, you do have some
other options later in terms of building
it up. But you ultimately build your
gradient bar in combat. And then
depending on the level it's at, one,
two, or three, you get to use those uh
gradient attacks. Now, it's probably
worth a mention though that if you have
a full level three gradient bar and you
only use a level one attack, you get to
keep those other two bars. It does build
sort of collectively as combat goes on.
And some of the level three ones are
devastating. In fact, Mel's was a real
lifesaver in terms of some of the
in-game battles. But before we wrap up
this section, just as a little bit of a
reminder, uh the reason I think whether
you like this game or not is going to
come down to this combat system is
because there's not really a lot of ways
to avoid this system. It's obviously a
huge part of the game, but again, even
the difficulty part uh outside of the
critical path, which is relatively easy
anyway due to the way the level scaling
works, a lot of the side stuff, the
optional content, etc., If you fail
these QT E or the dodges or the parries,
you just die. Doesn't actually matter
what the difficulty is on. And
especially in the optional encounters
where enemies can just do that
repeatedly before you get a chance to
attack, which is why the extra turns on
your characters are so important, it's
very possible they'll wipe out your
entire party before you even have a
chance to do anything. So, it winds up
being a case of if you enjoy that or you
can sort of learn to find ways to enjoy

you're going to have a good time with
for sure. Now, if you do enjoy this

potentially exclusive loot along the
